metadata.title: Electroporated recombinant proteins as tools for in vivo functional

abstract.text: Delivery of native or chemically modified recombinant proteins into mammalian cells shows 31 promise for functional investigations and various technological applications, but concerns 32 that sub-cellular localization and functional integrity of delivered proteins may be affected 33 remain high. Here, we surveyed batch electroporation as a delivery tool for single 34 polypeptides and multi-subunit protein assemblies of kinetochores, a spatially confined and 35 well-studied subcellular structures. After electroporation in human cells, recombinant 36 fluorescent Ndc80 and Mis12 multi-subunit complexes displayed native localization, 37 physically interacted with endogenous binding partners, and functionally complemented 38 depleted endogenous counterparts to promote mitotic checkpoint signaling and 39 chromosome segregation. Farnesylation is required for kinetochore localization of the 40 Dynein adaptor Spindly. In cells with chronically inhibited farnesyl transferase activity, in 41 vitro farnesylation and electroporation reconstituted robust kinetochore localization of 42

Spindly. Thus, electroporation is uniquely versatile for delivering synthetic and, as required, 43 chemically modified functional mimics of endogenous proteins, and is therefore a promising 44 tool for chemical and synthetic biology.

body_text.text: can reach very high concentrations, we observed linear uptake characteristics over a broad 140 range of input protein concentrations in the EP slurry ( Figure S1A-B) , indicating that EP 141 allows for semi-quantitative delivery of recombinant proteins. In turn, this allows for the 142 generation of cell populations harboring defined amounts of exogenously delivered proteins 143 ( Figure S1C-D) . Importantly, EP is efficient across multiple cell lines and treated cells show 144 little or no sign of damage or toxicity ( Figure S1A and D-F). 145

Previously, we generated various recombinant versions of stable sub-complexes of the 146 human kinetochore, and demonstrated that they could be used to reconstitute large parts of 147 the kinetochore and of the spindle assembly checkpoint (SAC) in vitro (1, 28, 31, 32) . This 148 library of high-quality recombinant samples ( Figure S2 ) already extensively characterized in 149 vitro represented an excellent resource to address the general suitability of EP for in vivo 150 delivery and functional analysis. 151

We initially tested this approach on BUBR1 (BUB1-related), a multi-domain protein that 152 operates in the SAC. Recombinant BUBR1 1-571 (encompassing residues 1-571 of the 1050-153 residue BubR1 protein, which are sufficient for checkpoint function) (1) fused to a cyan 154 fluorescent protein (CFP) was introduced into HeLa cells at an EP slurry concentration of 155 10 . In mitotically arrested cells (by addition of the spindle poison nocodazole, a 156 condition that activates the SAC), CFP-BUBR1 1-571 distinctly localized to kinetochores, as 157 revealed by the typical punctuate staining and by co-localization with CREST, an established 158 kinetochore marker ( Figure 1C) . We have shown previously that BUBR1 kinetochore 159 recruitment in human cells requires dimerization with kinetochore-bound BUB1, a BUBR1 160 paralog, through segments that encompass a predicted helical domain in the two proteins 161 (33). In agreement with these previous observations, recombinant CFP-BUBR1 1-571-∆Helix , a 162 deletion mutant of BUBR1 lacking the BUB1 binding helix (deletion of residues 432-484) 163 was unable to localize to kinetochores (Figure 1D-F) . Collectively, these results demonstrate 164 that, following EP, recombinant CFP-BUBR1 1-571 binds to its endogenous kinetochore 165 receptor BUB1 in target cells. The efficiency of CFP-BUBR1 1-571 delivery was high and most 166 cells displayed uniform levels of the recombinant protein ( Figure S3) . Thus, electroporation 167 can deliver very similar amounts of recombinant protein into each cell. In the course of this 168 study, this became to be recognized as a general feature of this approach, largely 169 independently of the protein used. 170

We used the Sortase method (34) to fuse a fluorescent peptide modified with the dye tetra-171 methyl-rhodamine (TAMRA) to the C-terminus of MAD2, another SAC protein. The 172 resulting MAD2 TAMRA was delivered by EP in HeLa cells at an EP-slurry concentration of 5 173 . Like CFP-BUBR1 1-571 , MAD2 TAMRA was found to localize effectively at kinetochores of 174 nocodazole-treated cells, as shown by co-localization with CREST ( Figure 1G) . 175

Furthermore, we performed co-delivery of CFP-BUBR1 1-571 with MAD2 TAMRA , and found 176 both proteins at unattached KTs in nocodazole-arrested cells ( Figure 1H) . Thus, individual 177 or multiple fluorophore-tagged components of the human KT are faithfully targeted to their 178 respective binding sites after EP. 179

In addition to localization studies, we tested if EP can be used in combination with in-cell 180 spectroscopic applications, such as FLIM-FRET microscopy (35), to study the 181 spatiotemporal dynamics of recombinant proteins in vivo. KRAS/p21 is a small, globular 182

GTPase with important regulatory functions in many signaling pathways (36). We studied 183 found that EGFP-TF3-KRAS, but not EGFP, predominantly localize to the plasma 191 membrane (Figure S4B) , with a pattern indistinguishable from endogenous, over-expressed, 192 or microinjected . Following addition of EGF, we observed the predicted 193 increase in the donor lifetime of EGFP-TF3-KRAS (Figure S4C-D) . Importantly, our based results were qualitatively and quantitatively identical to the ones that were observed in 195 EGFP-TF3-KRAS microinjection experiments (37), demonstrating the suitability of EP for 196

FRET-based assays in living cells as a valid alternative to protein delivery by microinjection. The copyright holder for this preprint (which was not peer-reviewed) is the author/funder. It . https://doi.org/10.1101/631358 doi: bioRxiv preprint depletion of the endogenous complex

body_text.text: The experiments discussed in the previous section described delivery of single polypeptides. 201

Next, we tested the suitability of EP for delivery of multi-subunit protein complexes. To this 202 end, we started with the Mis12 complex (MIS12C, where 'C' stands for 'complex'), an 203 extremely stable four-subunit kinetochore assembly of the DSN1, NSL1, MIS12, and PMF1 204 subunits with molecular mass of 120 kDa. In previous studies, we demonstrated that the 205 stability of the MIS12C requires co-expression of all four constituent subunits and reported 206 the development of various co-expression vectors for its heterologous reconstitution in 207 insect cells (39-41). Here we generated a fluorescence version of MIS12C by fusing the 208 coding sequence of cyan fluorescent protein (CFP) to that of the PMF1 subunit. We then 209 co-expressed the subunits in insect cells and purified the resulting complex (CFP-MIS12C) 210
to homogeneity ( Figure S2) . 211

We electroporated CFP-MIS12C into cycling HeLa cells and monitored CFP-MIS12C levels 212 by fluorescent microscopy. At an EP slurry concentration of 8  CFP-MIS12C was 213 clearly visible at kinetochores in the large majority of electroporated cells and with 214 remarkably similar kinetochore levels within the same cell and between different cells 215 ( Figure 2B and Figure S3C ). The ability of the electroporated CFP-MIS12C to reach 216 kinetochores after introduction in the cellular environment indicates that the complex retains 217 its integrity through the electroporation process. 218

In a more stringent test, we also asked if CFP-MIS12C retained its expected kinetochore 219 function after electroporation. MIS12C is as an assembly hub for the kinetochore, being 220 responsible for the recruitment of a subset of the microtubule-binding NDC80 complexes as 221 well as of KNL1, a signaling platform for the SAC (41, 42) ( Figure 1A) . These functions 222 make MIS12C necessary for timely chromosome congression and faithful cell division. To 223 test the functionality of the recombinant CFP-MIS12 complex, we performed a 224 complementation assay in HeLa cells depleted of endogenous MIS12 complex by the RNA 225 interference (RNAi) methods using silencing RNAs (siRNAs) against multiple subunits, as 226 previously described (43). Effective depletion of MIS12C subunits and uptake of fluorescent 227 proteins was demonstrated by Western blotting (Figure 2A) . This is noteworthy, as it 228 exposes a fundamental advantage of EP over another protein targeting technique such as 229 . CC-BY-NC-ND 4.0 International license is made available under a The copyright holder for this preprint (which was not peer-reviewed) is the author/funder. It . https://doi.org/10.1101/631358 doi: bioRxiv preprint microinjection, which is limited to a small number of target cells and therefore unsuitable to 230 biochemical analyses. In agreement with previous reports, depletion of MIS12C 231 compromised chromosome congression ( Figure 2B-C) , a consequence of reduced 232 kinetochore levels of NDC80 and KNL1 (43). As shown by live-cell microscopy, EP 233 delivery of CFP-MIS12C into depleted cells, but not of a CFP control, rescued chromosome 234 congression essentially to the levels observed in control cells, indicating that the recombinant 235 complex is functionally active (Figure 2B- The copyright holder for this preprint (which was not peer-reviewed) is the author/funder. It . https://doi.org/10.1101/631358 doi: bioRxiv preprint shape consisting of a coiled-coil shaft flanked by terminal globular domains, the four-subunit 261 NDC80C complex reaches approximately 60 nm in length (31, 45). We were curious to 262 assess if extreme elongation of NDC80C affected EP efficiency. As for the MIS12C, also the 263 ~180 kDa NDC80C achieves stability through co-expression of its four subunits (NUF2, 264 SPC24, SPC25, and NDC80) in insect cells ((40, 45) ; Figure 1A The copyright holder for this preprint (which was not peer-reviewed) is the author/funder. It . https://doi.org/10.1101/631358 doi: bioRxiv preprint sensed by an error correction mechanism that, by regulating the phosphorylation state of the 291 unstructured N-terminal region of the NDC80 subunit, causes the destabilization of 292 incorrect attachment and the formation of new, correct ones (46). A previously described 293 NDC80 mutant (9A) carrying nine alanine mutations at the phosphorylation sites in the 294 protein's N-terminus establishes hyper-stable KT-MT attachments that cannot be corrected, 295 resulting in frequent chromosome congression errors (47) (48) (49) . We asked if a NDC80C 9A -296 GFP mutant electroporated in HeLa cells had dominant-negative effects in an established 297 biorientation and error correction assay (50). HeLa cells were allowed to enter mitosis in 298 presence of STLC, an inhibitor of the Eg5 kinesin (51) whose activity is crucially required for 299 centrosome separation and spindle bipolarization, resulting in the accumulation of 300 monopolar spindles in which sister kinetochores frequently attach to the same microtubule 301 organizing center (MTOC, the centrosome in this case) in a condition known as synthelic 302 attachment. Upon washout of STLC, Eg5 reactivation, and spindle bipolarization, a 303 functional error correction pathway is required to resolve the synthelic attachments and 304 achieve correct metaphase alignment (50). In this setup, control cells electroporated with 305 GFP or NDC80C WT -GFP corrected erroneous attachments and aligned their chromosomes 306

properly at the metaphase plate ( Figure 3E ). In contrast, cells electroporated with the 307 NDC80C 9A -GFP mutant were impaired in their correction pathway, and accumulated 308 Spindly is an adaptor protein that promotes the interaction of the minus-end-directed motor 315

Dynein with its processivity factor Dynactin (52, 53). Spindly also interacts directly with the 316 ROD-Zwilch-ZW10 (RZZ) complex, the main constituent of the so-called kinetochore 317 corona, a crescent-shaped structure that assembles on kinetochores in early prometaphase to 318 promote microtubule capture (54) (Figure 1A) . Kinetochore localization of Spindly critically 319 depends on its ability to interact with the RZZ complex (55, 56). The latter, in turn, requires 320 the irreversible post-translational isoprenylation of Spindly with a farnesyl moiety on cysteine 321 . It . https://doi.org/10.1101/631358 doi: bioRxiv preprint (57), we reasoned that we could exploit this reaction to promote kinetochore localization of 328 recombinant Spindly in cells experiencing a long-term blockade of FT activity. Two versions 329 of HsSpindly that were N-terminally fused to GFP or mCherry (molecular mass ~95 kDa) 330

were expressed in insect cells and purified to homogeneity ( Figure S2 ). Our previous mass 331 spectrometry analysis demonstrated that only trace farnesylation of Spindly takes place in 332 insect cells (57). When we EP-delivered fluorescent recombinant mCherry-Spindly into 333

HeLa cells, we detected a fluorescent signal at the periphery of kinetochores that was 334 comparable to the localization described for endogenous Spindly (Figure 4A The copyright holder for this preprint (which was not peer-reviewed) is the author/funder. The modification of biological macromolecules through the introduction of new 356 functionalities has progressed at a tremendous pace in recent years, enriching the palette of 357 tools for biological investigation with a wide spectrum of functionalities. For instance, 358 genetic code expansion, an approach that allows to introduce old and new chemical 359 functionalities into proteins, from synthetic, photostable fluorescent dyes with high quantum 360 yields to highly reactive activatable groups (e.g. UV-activated cross-linkers and click 361 chemistry tools), is undergoing an explosive development (3, 59). With rapid growth of 362 chemical and synthetic biology, the demand for robust methods to deliver modified 363 synthetic or semi-synthetic macromolecules into cells is growing (60). 364

While electroporation has been long recognized for its potential as a delivery approach, 365 questions have been raised regarding the degree of its invasiveness and damage inferred on 366 cellular structures, most notably membranes (61). Here, we have assessed the suitability of 367 batch EP for delivering recombinant proteins into living mammalian cells for various 368 applications in cell biology. In comparison to previous studies that focused on cytosolic 369 proteins devoid of specific localization, our focus was on kinetochores, which are small, 370 discrete subcellular structures. This was crucial, because it enabled a detailed assessment of 371 the effective degree of functional complementation of the electroporated samples. Our 372 results identify EP as a rapid, efficient, and semi-quantitative technique that enables the 373 delivery into various cultured mammalian cell lines of proteins of variable mass and 374 hydrodynamic radius, including the highly elongated NDC80C. Importantly, we provide 375 clear evidence that the delivered proteins remain structurally and functionally intact after 376 delivery, as witnessed by their correct kinetochore localization and, where applicable, ability 377 to complement RNAi-based depletion, dominant negative effects, and immunoprecipitation 378 with endogenous interacting partners. Thus, in addition to its ease of application, EP is very 379 attractive because it allows delivery in sufficiently large cohorts of cells, and is therefore 380 compatible with cell biochemistry, as clearly shown here. 381 . CC-BY-NC-ND 4.0 International license is made available under a The copyright holder for this preprint (which was not peer-reviewed) is the author/funder. It . https://doi.org/10.1101/631358 doi: bioRxiv preprint chemical modifications of the probes, for instance by introduction of acutely activatable 384 crosslinking groups, EP may become a method of choice for the identification of elusive 385 binding partners (for instance, low affinity substrates of enzymes) with high spatial and 386 temporal resolution. Here, we have demonstrated how the introduction of a farnesyl chain in 387 vitro rescued the kinetochore localization of Spindly in cells treated with a farnesyl 388 transferase inhibitor. In the future, this approach may be extended to other lipid 389 modifications, and may allow monitoring the behavior of only one or a few modified 390 proteins at the time. Another obvious advantage of in vitro manipulations of macromolecules 391 is that it allows precision labeling with small fluorescent dyes, potentially bypassing limits 392 associated with tagging target proteins with bulky genetically encoded fluorescent proteins. 393

In this context, EP would expand the toolbox of reagents suitable for live-cell spectroscopic 394 applications such as FLIM-FRET microscopy or FRAP analysis. In summary, we envision 395 that EP has the potential to become a method of choice for delivery of synthetic or semi-396 synthetic proteins into the cellular environment. Following EP, the slurry was added to 50 ml of pre-412 warmed PBS, sedimented by a 0.5xg centrifugation and trypsinised for 5 to 7 minutes to 413 remove non-internalized extracellular protein. Following one further wash in PBS and 414 centrifugation, the cell pellet was re-suspended in complete imaging medium (without 415 antibiotics) and transferred to a cell-imaging plate (Ibidi). Cells were returned to the 416 incubator and allowed to recover for a minimum of 5 hrs. After recovery, cells were either 417 analyzed by fluorescence microscopy imaging or processed to generate protein extracts to be 418 used for either immunoprecipitation analysis or western blotting. 419 EP with the Amaxa system was performed according to the reported protocol (21). EP 420 conditions described above gave satisfactory results for all the cell types and proteins tested. 421
Only a small fraction of the tested recombinant proteins proved unsuitable for EP delivery. 422

This was due to formation of major intracellular aggregates or because the protein samples 423 failed to localize correctly within the cell. We advise to initially vary EP parameters, most 424 notably pulse strength and duration, for optimal performance. Moreover, cell-specific and 425

protein-specific optimization of such parameter should be always carried out in order to 426 achieve the best trade-off between cell viability and efficient protein delivery. The following 427 are some of the important factor to consider during optimization of protein delivery: 1) In 428 our work, we invariably used protein samples of great purity and homogeneity (high 429 monodispersity and solubility). Although we did not systematically analyze the relationship 430 between protein homogeneity and efficiency of EP, we suspect that protein sample quality is 431 an important factor. 2) Centrifugation of protein sample prior to EP is strongly 432 Actin IgM (Merck Millipore, JLA20, 1:5,000 dilution). FIGREF0.text: 184 coupled human KRAS (i.e. EGFP-TF3-KRAS, final size ~50 kDa), a conformational-change 185 FRET sensor purified from E. coli (37) (Figure S4A). Activation and conformational 186 switching of EGFP-TF3-KRAS occurs upon epidermal growth factor (EGF) stimulation 187 and causes the spatial separation of the fluorescence moieties and a concomitant loss of 188 intramolecular FRET signal, which ultimately results in an increase of the donor 189 fluorescence lifetime measured by FLIM-FRET live microscopy (37). Upon EP-delivery, we 190

FIGREF2.text: ). After expression and 265 purification with an established protocol of a fluorescent version of the complex containing 266 NDC80-GFP (Figure S2), we electroporated it into cycling HeLa cells at an EP slurry 267 concentration of 5 µM. 12 hours after electroporation, cells were imaged by live cell video-268 microscopy. This revealed kinetochore localization of the recombinant NDC80-GFP 269 complex (Figure 3A), indicating that the considerable length of the complex is compatible 270 with efficient delivery. 271 HeLa cells carrying recombinant NDC80C-GFP in addition to endogenous NDC80C 272 displayed no alterations in cell cycle progression and proceeded through the different stages 273 of mitosis without detectable changes when compared to control cells (Figure 3A-B and 274 Supplementary movies S5-S9). Thus, delivering exogenous NDC80C-GFP does not cause 275 obvious cell cycle alterations or cytotoxicity. When NDC80C-GFP was electroporated into 276 other human cell lines, such as RPE, HEK293 and U2OS, equally clear kinetochore signals 277 were observed (Figure 3C). 278 To test weather recombinant NDC80C-GFP complexes establish their expected physical 279 interactions after EP delivery, we performed GFP-immunoprecipitation (GFP-IP) assays on 280 protein extracts generated from mitotic HeLa cells previously electroporated with NDC80C-281 GFP. Western blotting demonstrated that MIS12 and BUB1 were present in the NDC80C-282 GFP precipitates, but not in precipitates of GFP (Figure 3D). Thus, the electroporated 283 NDC80-GFP establishes physiologic interactions with its endogenous binding partners, 284 demonstrating the versatility of EP as a technique to probe protein interactions in living cells 285 both through imaging and through biochemistry. 286 287 An NDC80C mutant triggers a dominant-negative chromosome alignment defect 288Chromosome bi-orientation implies that the sister kinetochores attach to microtubules 289 emanating from opposite spindle poles. Incorrect attachments that occur during mitosis are 290

FIGREF3.text: misaligned chromosomes with high frequency. Thus, recombinant NDC80C 9A -GFP 309 electroporated in HeLa cells exercises a dominant-negative effect on the ability of 310 endogenous NDC80C to promote chromosome alignment. 311 312 In vitro farnesylation allows Spindly localization when farnesyl transferase is 313 inhibited 314

FIGREF4.text: -B) (55), or of 335 Spindly introduced by microinjection (unpublished observation). mCherry-Spindly C602A , a 336 mutant that cannot be farnesylated, failed to show any KT localization upon EP (Figure 4A-337 B). This indicated that wild type mCherry-Spindly becomes farnesylated after intracellular 338 delivery. To further substantiate this, we treated cells with FTI-227, a selective farnesyl-339 transferase inhibitor (58). In presence of FTI-227, localization of recombinant mCherry-340 Spindly or GFP-Spindly was greatly reduced (Figure 4B-C), confirming that FT activity is 341 required for Spindly localization. 342 We therefore asked if in vitro farnesylation by FT rescued the localization of Spindly in cells 343 treated with FTI-227. mCherry-Spindly was farnesylated in vitro with recombinant 344 farnesyltransferase (FT) and farnesyl-pyrophosphate as a substrate, as described previously 345 (57). The resulting farnesylated mCherry-Spindly (mCherry-Spindly F ) and untreated GFP-346 Spindly were co-electroporated at the same EP slurry concentration (10 µM) in HeLa cells 347 that had been treated with FTI-227 for the previous 24 hours. Remarkably, mCherry-348 Spindly F , but not GFP-Spindly, successfully targeted kinetochores, showing that the 349 complementation of FT activity in vitro had bypassed the blockade of FT activity in cells by 350 FTI-227. Although we do not provide formal proof, the persistent treatment with FT 351

FIGREF5.text: EP) was performed using either the Neon Transfection System Kit 401 (Thermo Fisher) or the Amaxa Nucleofector I system (Lonza). For EPs with Neon 402 Transfection System, cells were harvested by trypsinisation, washed with PBS, and 403 resuspended in Buffer R (Thermo Fisher) to a final volume of 90 µl. Protein samples were 404 diluted 1:1 in buffer R and then a volume of 30 µl of this mix was added to the cell 405 suspension (the EP slurry). Volumes and protein-buffer ratios may be adjusted according to 406 the purpose of the experiment and depending on protein solubility. Final protein 407 concentrations in the respective EP slurry varied between 5 and 200 µM (in a final volume of 408 110 L). The EP slurry was loaded into a 100 µl Neon Pipette Tip (Thermo Fisher) and 409 electroporated with 2 consecutives pulses at 1000V and for durations of 35 msec (with the 410 exception of the experiments in U2OS, RPE and HEK293 cells, which were electroporated 411

FIGREF6.text: During the recovery phase, we recommend avoiding the use of selection 433 antibiotics in the media as they increase cell mortality. 4) Once resuspended in EP buffer, 434 cells should be electroporated and washed as fast as possible to reduce cytotoxicity. 5) If 435 required, including additional trypsinization and washing steps following EP may improve 436 the removal of persistent extracellular protein aggregates generated during EP. 437 expression exploited the MultiBac baculovirus expression system (62). A Bacmid was then 449 produced from EMBacY cells and subsequently used to transfect Sf9 cells and produce 450 baculovirus. Baculovirus was amplified through three rounds of amplification and used to 451 infect Tnao38 cells. Cells infected with virus were cultured for 72 h before harvesting. Cell 452 pellets were resuspended in buffer A (50 mM HEPES pH 8, 200 mM NaCl, 20 mM 453Imidazole, 5% glycerol, 2 mM TCEP) supplemented with protease-inhibitor mix from 454 Serva and 0.2% Triton, lysed by sonication and cleared by centrifugation. NDC80C 9A -455 GFP was then eluted in buffer B (50 mM HEPES pH 8, 200 mM NaCl, 300 mM 456 Imidazole, 5% glycerol, 2 mM TCEP) and the eluate was diluted 6 times in volume using 457 ion exchange buffer C (50 mM HEPES pH 8, 25 mM NaCl, 5% glycerol, 2 mM TCEP, 1 458 mM EDTA) and applied to a 6 mL Resource Q anion-exchange column pre-equilibrated 459 in the same buffer. Elution of bound protein was achieved by a linear gradient (25-400 460 mM NaCl in 25 column volumes). Relevant fractions were concentrated in 10 kDa 461 molecular mass cut-off Amicon concentrators and applied to a Superose 6 16/70 column 462 equilibrated in size-exclusion chromatography buffer D (50 mM HEPES pH 8, 250 mM 463 NaCl, 5% glycerol, 2 mM TCEP). Peak fractions containing the NDC80C 9A -GFP complex 464were collected and further concentrated in a 10 kDa cut-off Amicon concentrator before 465 being flash frozen in liquid N2 and stored at -80°C. Recombinant CFP-MIS12 complex 466 was generated by fusing N-terminal CFP to PMF1. Baculoviral transfer vectors encoding 467 CFP-Mis12C expression were generated using biGBac platform (63). Baculoviruses were 468 generated in Sf9 cells, and expression of CFP-tagged MIS12C was carried out in Tnao38 469 cells for 72h-96h, at 27C. CFP-Mis12C was purified by a three-step protocol, as described470 previously for the non-fluorescent version (39): i) affinity purification of filtered supernatant 471 with 5 ml HisTrap FF column (GE Healthcare) and step elution with 300 mM imidazole; ii) 472 anion-exchange of the dialyzed eluate with 6 ml Resource Q column, elution with linear 473 PMSF). Soluble lysates were passed over a 5-ml Ni-NTA column and, after 479 washing with 20 column volumes buffer A, the proteins were eluted by adding 300 mM 480 imidazole to buffer A. Proteins were subsequently gel-filtered on a Superdex S200 16/60 481 column equilibrated against buffer B (10 mM HEPES (pH 7.5), 150 mM NaCl, 5% 482 glycerol, 2 mM TCEP). Fractions containing purified protein were concentrated, flash-483 frozen and stored at -80 °C. Recombinant N-terminally acetylated human -484 SYNUCLEIN (SYN) was purified from E. coli as reported (21). In vitro pre-farnesylation 485 of mCherry-Spindly (30 µM) was achieved by incubation with recombinant 486 Farnesyltransferase (10 M) and Farnesylpyrophosphate (90 µM) for 5-6 hours at 20°C, 487 followed by gel filtration (S200) purification to remove the Farnesyltransferase. 488 489 Cell culture, siRNA transfection, immunoprecipitation, immunoblotting and analysis 490 of intracellular protein levels 491 The following cell lines were cultured in DMEM (PAN Biotech) supplemented with 10 % 492 FBS (Clontech), penicillin, streptomycin (GIBCO) and 2 mM L-glutamine (PAN Biotech): 493 HeLa, mCherry-H2B HeLa, U2OS, MDCK, HEK293, and RPE. Human A2780, SK-N-SH 494 and SH-SY5Y cells were grown in RPMI 1640, DMEM-Ham's F-12 and DMEM 495 respectively. Cells were grown at 37 °C in the presence of 5% CO 2 . All experiments requiring 496 live imaging were performed in complemented CO 2 -independent medium (GIBCO) at 497 37 °C. Cells used in this study are regularly checked for mycoplasma contamination. Cell 498 lines were not authenticated. Unless differently indicated, the microtubule-depolimerising 499 drug nocodazole was used at 3.3 M (Sigma). Endogenous farnseyltransferase inhibition was 500 achieved at 10 M of FTI-277 (Sigma). Cellular RAS activity was stimulated with 50ng/ml 501 EGF (Sigma). Were indicated, the DNA dye SiR-Hoechst-647 Dye (Spirochrome) at a 502 concentration of 0.5 µM was added to the medium 1 hour before live imaging. Depletion of 503 by shake off and resuspended in lysis buffer [150 mM KCl, 75 mM Hepes, 510 pH 7.5, 1.5 mM EGTA, 1.5 mM MgCl 2 , 10 % glycerol, and 0.075 % NP-40 supplemented 511 with protease inhibitor cocktail (Serva) and PhosSTOP phosphatase inhibitors (Roche)]. A 512 total of 4 mgs of protein extract per sample was then incubated with GFP-Traps beads 513 (ChromoTek; 3 μl/mg of extract) for 3 hours at 4 °C. Immunoprecipitates were washed with 514 lysis buffer and resuspended in sample buffer, boiled and analyzed by SDS-PAGE and 515 Western blotting using 4-12 % gradient gels (NuPAGE). The following antibodies were used 516 for the western blot analysis in this study: anti-Bub1 (rabbit polyclonal; Abcam; 1:5000), anti-517 Hec1 (human Ndc80; mouse clone 9G3.23; Gene-Tex, Inc.; 1:250), anti-Mis12 (in house 518 made mouse monoclonal antibody; clone QA21; 1:1000), anti-GFP (in house made rabbit 519 polyclonal antibody; 1:1,000-4,000) anti-Vinculin (mouse monoclonal; clone hVIN-1; Sigma-520 Aldrich; 1:10000), anti PMF1/NNF1 (in house made mouse affinity purified monoclonal; 521 clone RH25-1-54, 1:1000) and anti-Tubulin (mouse monoclonal, Sigma-Aldrich; 1:10000). 522 Quantification of protein levels from western blots was performed with the following 523 formula: [(LPoIsiRNA-PoIBgr)/(LVincsiRNA-VincBgr)]/[(LPoICtrl-PoIBgr)/(LVincCtrl-524 VincBgr)]. LPoIsiRNA= levels of the protein of interest for the siRNA lane; PoIBgr= 525 background signal for the protein of interest; LVincsiRNA= levels of Vinculin for the 526 siRNA lane; VincBgr= background signal for Vinculin; LPoICtrl= levels of the protein of 527 interest for the Control lane; PoIBgr= background signal for the protein of interest; 528 LVincCtrl= levels of Vinculin for the Control lane; VincBgr= background signal for 529 Vinculin. Fluorimetric analysis was performed using Greiner flat-bottom plates and a 530 Clariostar microplate reader (monochromator excitation at 587+/-10 nm, emission 610 +/-531 10 nM). Fluorescence intensity from protein extracts derived from a known number of 532 electroporated cells were measured and plotted against a calibration curve generated with 533 defined concentrations of recombinant mCherry. Bar graphs show average intracellular 534 µM), cells were recovered for 5 hrs in the incubator on poly-L-lysine-540 coated 25 mm cover slips. Cells were quickly washed 3  with complete medium and treated 541 briefly with diluted trypsin/EDTA (0.01 %/ 0.004 %, 40 s, room temperature) to remove 542 non-internalized SYN, then fixed in PBS containing 4 % (w/v) PFA for 15 min and 543 permeabilized with 0.1 % (v/v) Triton-X in PBS for 3 min. After washing 3  10 min with 544 PBS, samples were blocked with 0.13 % (v/v) cold fish skin gelatin (Sigma) in PBS for 1 h. 545Cells were incubated for 2 hrs with anti-SYN ab52168 (Abcam, 1:100 dilution) in blocking 546 buffer. After washing 3  10 min with PBS, specimens were incubated with anti-mouse IgG 547Atto647, (Sigma, 1:1000 dilution) and fluorescein isothiocyanate (FITC)-labeled phalloidin 548 (Millipore, 2 mg/mL) for 1 h in blocking buffer. Slides were washed 3  10 min with PBS 549 and nuclei stained with 1 µg/mL 4',6-diamidino-2-phenylindole (DAPI, Invitrogen) in PBS 550 for 15 min. After washing once in PBS, samples were mounted with Immu-Mount (Thermo 551 Scientific). For SYN detection by western blotting, cell lysates were separated on 552 commercial 4-18 % gradient SDS-PAGE (BioRad), transferred onto PVDF membranes and 553 fixed with 4 % (w/v) paraformaldehyde (PFA) in PBS for 1 h. Membranes were washed 2  554 5 min with PBS and 2  5 min with TBS (25 mM Tris, 136.9 mM NaCl, 2.7 mM KCl, pH 555 7.4). Simultaneous 606 electroporation of 10 µM CFP-BUBR1 1-571 and 5 µM MAD2 TAMRA was performed on HeLa 607 cells and imaged live on a Deltavision system. To measure mitotic duration in cells depleted 608 for endogenous MIS12C and electroporated with recombinant CFP-MIS12C at 8 µM, H2B-609 mCherry HeLa cells were transfected with siRNA-MIS12C oligos, twice in 24 hours, and 610 then electroporated 6 hours after the second transfection. Following EP, cells recovered 611 overnight before being processed for either western blotting analysis or imaged lived on the 612 Deltavision system. Mitotic duration, with or without 330 nM nocodazole, was assessed by 613 DNA morphology. Cells entering anaphase with their DNA not completely aligned in the 614 metaphase plate were scored as erroneous segregations. Between 53 and 149 cells per 615 condition were scored. Live-cell time-lapse imaging of HeLa cells electroporated with 616 NDC80C WT -GFP at 5 µM was performed on an asynchronously growing population. Cells 617were then left to recover overnight before being treated with SiR-Hoechst-647 Dye for one 618 hour before being imaged live on a Deltavision system. To determine mitotic duration, 619 between 60 and 70 cells per condition were scored. For the error correction assay, following 620 electroporation HeLa cells were synchronized in G2 with 9 µM RO-3306 (Millipore) for 16 621 hours and then released in the presence of 5 µM STLC (Sigma-Aldrich) for 3 hours.622 Following STLC wash-out, cells were grown for 150 minutes in media containing 5 µM 623 MG132 (Calbiochem), then fixed, prepared for immunofluorescence analysis and then 624 scored for the presence of uncongressed chromosomes on the Mariana microscope. Cells 625 with one or more chromosomes not perfectly aligned at the metaphase plate were scored as 626 are representing the average  SD of two replicated experiments. In 627 total, between 140 and 191 cells were scored for each condition. Electroporation of cell lines, thus, for these lines, we recommend a protein-specific optimisation of EP 633 parameters in order to achieve proper cell viability. For Spindly experiments, asynchronously 634 growing HeLa cells were treated with farnesyltransferase inhibitor FTI for 24 hours before 635 being electroporated with fluorescent Spindly at 10 µM. Following EP, cells were left to 636 recover for 24 hours in FTI-277, of which the last 6 hours were in the presence of 637 nocodazole. Immunofluorescence analysis was performed on the Mariana system. To 638 determine kinetochore levels for fluorescent SPINDLY, between 60 and 220 KTs per 639 condition were scored. For EGFP-KRAS D30C-TF3 experiments, microinjections and 640 electroporations for FLIM-FRET imaging were performed on MDCK cells that were serum-641 starved overnight in MEM Eagle medium (Sigma) supplemented with 0.5% FBS. Following 642 starvation, cells were either microinjected or electroporated with EGFP-KRAS D30C-TF3 643 at a concentration of 6-10 mg/mL and then left recover for 6 hours before live-cell imaging 644 by FLIM-FRET microscopy. Microinjections and FLIM-FRET imaging were performed on 645 an Olympus FV1000 as previously described (37). FLIM-FRET analysis of EGFP-KRAS 646 D30C-TF3 lifetime was performed on 12 electroporated cells. 647 648 Acknowledgments 649 We thank Alex Faesen, Melina Schuh, Dean Clift, and all members of the Selenko and 650 Musacchio laboratories for helpful discussions and comments. We thank Pim Joannes Huis 651 in`t Veld for his support in the generation of the GFP-NDC80C-9A mutant. We thank 652 Philippe Bastiaens for support with the KRAS FLIM-FRET analysis. A.M. gratefully 653 acknowledges funding by the Max Planck Society and the European Research Council 654 (ERC) Advanced Investigator Grant RECEPIANCE (proposal number nº 669686).

FIGREF13.text: Schematic outline of a mitotic cell with condensed chromosomes (grey) and centromeres 804 (blue). The inner kinetochore (red) recruits several outer kinetochore proteins (orange 805 gradient box), including the MIS12 (MIS12C) and the microtubule (MT) binding complex 806 NDC80 (NDC80C). In turn, these complexes recruit the protein KNL1, the spindle 807 assembly checkpoint (SAC) components BUB1, BUBR1, MAD1 and MAD2, and the outer 808 kinetochore proteins RZZ and Spindly. B) Overview of the electroporation (EP) work-flow 809 using adherent cells. (1) Cells are cultured under defined growth conditions according to 810 experimental requirements. (2) Prior to EP, cells are harvested by trypsinization, washed in 811 PBS, counted and resuspended in EP buffer. (3) Recombinant protein diluted in EP buffer is 812 added to cell slurries at desired concentrations (this stage is called EP slurry). (4) Cells are 813 pulsed between 1 and 3-times to allow for efficient delivery of recombinant proteins. (5) 814 Cells are tripsinised and then washed twice to remove non-incorporated protein, and then 815 plated on cover slips or culture flasks to allow for recovery. (6) After a recovery period, cells 816 are processed for imaging. C) Following EP of CFP-BUBR1 1-571 and over-night recovery, 817 cells were treated for 6 hours with nocodazole and then prepared for immunofluorescence 818 analysis. Kinetochores were stained with the marker CREST and DNA with SiR-Hoechst-819 647. Insets represents magnifications of the boxed kinetochores. Scale bar = 5 µm. D) CFP 820 alone, CFP-BUBR1 1-571 and the BUB1-binding-deficient mutant CFP-BUBR1 1-571-Helix were 821 electroporated under the same conditions used in C. Protein extracts generated from 822 electroporated cells were subjected to western blotting analysis with the indicated antibodies. 823 E) CFP-BUBR1 1-571-Helix fails to localize to kinetochores. Kinetochores were stained with the 824 marker CREST and DNA with SiR-Hoechst-647. Scale bar = 5 m. F) Quantification of 825 KT levels for electroporated CFP proteins from cells shown in E. Each symbol represents a 826 single cell. Yellow lines indicate median values  interquartile range. G) SAC protein 827 MAD2 TAMRA electroporated into cells display proper localization to unattached kinetochores. 828 Kinetochores were stained with the marker CREST and DNA with DAPI. Scale bar = 5 829 m. Insets represent magnifications of the indicated KT. H) Simultaneous electroporation 830 complex targets kinetochores and functionally complements 836 depletion of the endogenous complex 837 A) The indicated proteins, including CFP-labeled recombinant MIS12C, were electroporated 838 in mCherry-H2B-expressing HeLa cells previously treated with siRNAs to deplete the 839 endogenous MIS12C. Western blotting of cellular protein levels in extracts was performed 840 and showed a depletion in MIS12 and PMF1 levels of 93,7% and 87,6% respectively. B) 841 Frames collected at the indicated time points (min) of time-lapse live-cell fluorescence 842 microscopy movies depicts chromosome congression and segregation of cells from A. Two 843 representative phenotypes observed in cells with depleted MIS12C that were concomitantly 844 electroporated with CFP as control are shown. Green and red signal represents, respectively, 845 CFP proteins and DNA. Scale bar = 5 µm. C) Quantification of chromosome congression 846 and segregation defects in B. Each symbol represents a single cell. Yellow lines indicate 847 mean values  SD. D) Electroporated CFP-MIS12C rescues SAC defects in H2B-mCherry 848 HeLa cells depleted for endogenous MIS12C. Duration of mitosis (based on DNA and cell 849 morphology) of individual cells treated as in A but imaged in the presence of nocodazole 0.3 850  was plotted. Yellow lines indicate mean values  SD. Cellular delivery of a protein complex with an exceptionally large hydrodynamic 854 radius 855 A) GFP-labeled recombinant NDC80C WT binds to kinetochores and its localization is 856 compatible with normal mitotic progression. Panels show timepoints of time-lapse movies 857 for asynchronously growing HeLa cells electroporated with recombinant GFP proteins and 858 imaged live every 10 minutes. DNA was stained with SiR-Hoechst-647 and is shown in red.  SD. C) Additional human cell lines were electroporated with NDC80C-GFP. RPE1 862 cells are non-transformed human retinal pigmented epithelium cells. HEK293 cells are 863 human epithelium kidney cells. U2OS cells are human osteosarcoma cells. Following 864 recovery and staining with SiR-Hoechst-647 DNA dye, cells were imaged live and display a 865 clearly visible kinetochore localization of the delivered NDC80C-GFP complex. Scale bar = 866 5 µm. D) Immunoprecipitation analysis of protein extracts from cells treated as in A shows 867 that EP-delivered NDC80C-GFP WT establishes normal interactions with its endogenous KT 868 partners. Western blotting panels show immunoprecipitates performed with -GFP beads 869 and probed with the indicated antibodies. E) An error correction assay for the EP-delivery 870 of a NDC80C 9A -GFP mutant shows a dominant-negative effect on the correction of 871 improper KT-MT attachments. Panels display representative images of electroporated HeLa 872 cells treated with STLC to accumulate erroneous synthelic KT-MT attachments, followed by 873 STLC washout, release into MG132 (proteasome inhibitor that prevents mitotic exit), and 874 fixation 150 minutes after STLC-release. Inability to correct erroneous attachments results in 875 uncongressed chromosomes. Control cells were electroporated with GFP alone. Numbers 876 represent the percentage of cells with uncongressed chromosomes for each condition. KTs 877 were labeled with anti-CREST immunostaining, microtubules (MT) with an anti-TUBULIN 878 antibody and DNA with DAPI. Insets represent magnificatis of the indicated KT. In vitro farnesylation allows Spindly localization when farnesyl transferase is 883 inhibited 884 A) Kinetochore localization of unmodified recombinant Spindly depends on cellular 885 farnesylation. Panels show representative images of cells transduced with unfarnesylated 886 mCherry-Spindly in nocodazole-treated HeLa cells. Mutation of Cys602 to alanine prevents 887 farnesylation upon EP and reduces KT levels of the delivered protein. Kinetochores were 888 stained with CREST antibodies and DNA with DAPI. Controls cells were electroporated 889 . Insets represent magnifications of the indicated kinetochores. Scale bar = 5 890 µm. B) Quantification of KT levels for electroporated Spindly from cells in A and C. Each 891 symbol represents a single cell. Yellow lines indicate mean values  SD. C) In vitro 892 farnesylation of mCherry-Spindly before EP bypasses the need of cellular farnesylation to 893 achieve kinetochore localization. Cells treated with the farnesyl-transferase inhibitor FTI-277 894 were electroporated with either GFP, GFP-Spindly, mCherry, mCherry-Spindly, or in vitro 895 pre-farnesylated mCherry-Spindly (mCherry-Spindly F ) and then processed for 896 immunofluorescence analysis. Kinetochores were stained for CREST and DNA with DAPI. 897 Insets represent magnifications of the indicated KT. FP= Fluorescent protein. Scale bar

TABREF0.text: C and Supplementary movies 1-4). Improperly attached kinetochores trigger the spindle assembly checkpoint (SAC), causing a 237 mitotic arrest that delays entry into anaphase (29). The checkpoint pathway exhausts its 238 function only after all chromosomes have achieved bi-orientation on the mitotic spindle. Despite causing dramatic chromosome congression failures, depletion of endogenous 240 MIS12C is hardly compatible with checkpoint function because cells lacking the MIS12C 241 also fail to recruit KNL1, which is required for SAC signaling. Thus, MIS12C depleted cells 242 have a strongly weakened SAC that results in their premature anaphase and mitotic exit (43, 243 44). To assess SAC function under our RNAi conditions, we treated cells with 0.3  of the 244 microtubule-depolymerizer nocodazole, thus creating conditions that potently activate 245 checkpoint signaling in control cells. We then measured, by live-cell video microscopy, the 246 cells' ability to sustain a prolonged mitotic arrest. In agreement with the previous studies, 247 cells depleted of MIS12C were unable to mount a strong mitotic arrest and underwent 248 mitotic exit in presence of multiple unattached or incompletely attached chromosomes, 249indicative of a checkpoint defect. Electroporated CFP was unable to restore the SAC 250 response, while recombinant CFP-MIS12C restored mitotic duration to values similar to 251 those observed in control cells, indicating full rescue of SAC activity (Figure 2D).Collectively, these results indicate that electroporated recombinant MIS12C targeted the KT 253 as a functionally intact complex and that EP can be used for biological complementation 254 assays in combination with knockdown or knockouts. 255EP of a protein complex with an exceptionally large hydrodynamic radius and itsWith a long axis of approximately 20 nm (39, 40) the MIS12C is rather elongated, a feature 259 that at least qualitatively does not appear to interfere with efficient EP.
